channel.title: squarepegsys | GeekLists | BoardGameGeek
channel.description: BoardGameGeek features information related to the board gaming hobby

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by suzyvitale

Related Item: Zulus on the Ramparts!

Sapper_SB wrote:

Suzy wrote:

Americans are definitely *not* as fierce as Zulu warriors.


Tell that to:
The guys at the Alamo
The guys who stormed the beaches in Normandy
The 101st in Bastogne
The 8th Air Force
The guys who fought at Gettysburg
Marcus Luttrell and Chris Kyle

I could go on....and on.


Yes! Love this list. I totally agree.

Let me clarify. American Colonists vs. Zulu Warriors....who seems more fierce? I think Zulus! But we will never know since this is a very silly comparison on my part. :D
item.dc:creator: suzyvitale

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by kerskine

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

I'm with Phil. Mage Knight is a great game. Pathfinder is a filler that I play when I don't want to think. The only reason it gets so many plays for me is that when I start, I want to see characters through to the end. The last time through, I think I had to redo 4 of the 30+ scenarios because I didn't win on the first go around. Nobody ever came close to dying.

Mage Knight never gets repetitive and every turn of every game has to be considered.
item.dc:creator: kerskine

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by philmcd

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

esbegan wrote:

Wow!!! those miniatures are great and playing that game in a rainy day...oooh nothing better, with a nice cup of coffee :D

Now I don't know if go for Mage Knight or Pathfinder! :D

Cheers


I'd give MK 10 and Pathfinder 4, but that's based on my preferences. Totally different game experiences of course, though there is much more replayability in MK from my experience.

Also depends on your preference for game length. For me MK is 3 hours whereas Pathfinder was about about 30-45 mins per play before I got bored of it.
item.dc:creator: philmcd

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by lightningbug_54

Related Item: The Undercity: An Iron Kingdoms Adventure Board Game

often wrote:

Wait, is Gorman deWulfe in this game? Do they actually use characters from the Iron Kingdoms stories/fluff?

I think I see Gorman's sculpt in the middle there.


No actual Warmachine characters in the game. They just re-used Gorman's sculpt. Milo is almost as good as Gorman though. His A0Es consistently wipe out large groups of enemies in a single actuation in our games.

I guess you can't use that sculpt & not make the character great!

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by philmcd

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

Longbombed wrote:

Roughly:

1 Kilogram= 2.2lbs
1 mile= 1.6 kilometers

... and heres a fairly accurate way to decipher *C and *F. Take the C multiply it by 2, then add 30. It's not perfect, but it's fairly close. So take 22*C, multiply it by 2 = 44 add 30, and it's about 74*F.


Yeah, it's only really the temperature that bugs me. I've got used to most of the rest (apart from the steak example) :D

Converting a mile into kilometers (I use 1.5 as a rough rule) is like converting pounds into dollars :D

I've heard your temp converter before, but for some reason I never remember it :(
item.dc:creator: philmcd

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by schroederjan

Related Item: into the woods

suzyvitale wrote:

Gizensha wrote:

Congratulations to the winners. Hopefully this will either wind up in print, or I'll get enough experience of P&P that I feel confident enough to try and make a copy for myself at some point.


Stephen, this was the first PnP I ever made. I am horribly uncrafty, and I rarely can cut in a straight line. But mine turned out pretty good, and it was fun to make! *You can do it.* :D


+1 to that! all you have to do is cut paper into (not so many) square forms. (granted, a paper knife, a steel ruler and a cutting mat help a lot!)

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by Scarge

Related Item: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game

Marlowespade wrote:

I am simultaneously mystified, terrified, and amped for the Big Trouble in Little China version of this. It's one of my favorite movies, but I have no earthly (HAR!) idea how they're going to get enough content out of one movie for a $50 Legendary game. You'd think they'd almost have to throw in a bunch of miscellaneous Chinese mythology just to have enough cards in the various decks for a single scenario.

Carpenter's fairly protective of his original material, as well so I'm wondering how much license they have to invent new things.

In fact, now that I think about it, what I really want now is Legendary Encounters: John Carpenter, with themed decks and scenarios from Big Trouble, The Thing, Escape From New York, and In The Mouth Of Madness. Heck, throw in Vampires* while we're at it!

* = Yes, I liked Vampires. Shut up.


"Forget whatever you've seen in the movies: they don't turn into bats, crosses don't work. Garlic? You wanna try garlic? You could stand there with garlic around your neck and one of these buggers will bend you fu%&ing over and take a walk up your strada-chocolata WHILE he's suckin' the blood outta your neck, all right?"

I think you need to pitch this Carpenter idea to Upper Deck, no really this needs to be a thing.
item.dc:creator: Scarge

item.description:
by Marlowespade

Related Item: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game

I am simultaneously mystified, terrified, and amped for the Big Trouble in Little China version of this. It's one of my favorite movies, but I have no earthly (HAR!) idea how they're going to get enough content out of one movie for a $50 Legendary game. You'd think they'd almost have to throw in a bunch of miscellaneous Chinese mythology just to have enough cards in the various decks for a single scenario.

Carpenter's fairly protective of his original material, as well so I'm wondering how much license they have to invent new things.

In fact, now that I think about it, what I really want now is Legendary Encounters: John Carpenter, with themed decks and scenarios from Big Trouble, The Thing, Escape From New York, and In The Mouth Of Madness. Heck, throw in Vampires* while we're at it!

* = Yes, I liked Vampires. Shut up.
item.dc:creator: Marlowespade

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by Al_Shrew

Related Item: Zulus on the Ramparts!

Although I think as a game Cruel Necessity is a better game, I actually love this one more. The film is my favourite film, of all time. I own multiple versions on multiple platforms. Much to my SOs dismay. I watch it several times a year (I suffer from mood swings and anxiety disorder, this film is the one that brings me back from the depths as it reminds me of some of the happier times I've had with family).

You should really try and get CN to the table soon, I'd be interested to hear your thoughts. I must warn you though my copy hates me and I'm sure it conspires with Robinson Crusoe, to make sure I suffer as much as possible during the game.
item.dc:creator: Al_Shrew

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by reverendunclebastard

Related Item: into the woods

Thank you so much Jan! And thanks again to everyone for the birthday wishes, felt great. Looking forward to trying out this beautiful game.

So I didn't get any birthday gaming in, but my girlfriend took me to the Toronto International Film Festival to see the Ben Wheatley adaptation of J.G. Ballard's High Rise. Incredible, surreal and visceral film. I highly recommend it, especially if you saw either Kill List or Sightseers (two of Ben Wheatley's other films) and enjoyed them.
item.dc:creator: reverendunclebastard

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by atony77

Related Item: Fortress Europa

I am currently playing this one. I only have 6 turns left. It took me a while to really get into the game, but that being said I do like. A lot of chrome on the game. I missed a few rules in the beginning, but it didn't help either side so I just continued to play. This is also my first war game. Their is a great solo variant that helps with the small amount of hidden information. Good Luck.
item.dc:creator: atony77

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by Scarge

Related Item: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game

How dare you bad mouth the masterpiece that was Predator 2, Gary Busey should have gotten an Oscar for that performance! :p :shake:

I actually like the way they nerfed single handed play, it was way too easy in Alien, with the exception of the fourth movie I rarely felt challenged playing single handed. I'm hoping someone is going to come up with a decent solo variant for the Hunter side of things, and we have the golf challenges to look forward to.

I'm also really hoping the Big Trouble In Little China version ends up happening, although i'm not sure how they'll make that work within the system.
item.dc:creator: Scarge

item.description:
by Scarge

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

suzyvitale wrote:

Longbombed wrote:

Been hitting 2 and 3 here in the evenings. That's like 35*F


Oh, I'm so jealous. :cry:


I'll swap geographic locations with you in a heartbeat for winter, but we have to switch back come summer. :p Don't get me wrong, I love my country but -40 Celsius can be a bit much(that's the same in Fahrenheit). Mind you I don't like it too hot either, guess you can just call me Goldilocks. :laugh:
item.dc:creator: Scarge

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by Scarge

Related Item: Hostage Negotiator

This is such a neat little game, nice for a quick challenge first thing in the morning or before bed. It's amazing to me how so few components can pull you right into the theme, and the tension can become palpable. Looking forward to the new content, and getting the abductor packs as well (I only have the base game currently).

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by joestin

Related Item: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game

pusherman42 wrote:

Welcome!

I'm completely in the minority on this one, but I would have preferred movie still for both this and Aliens.

The reason is that the source material IS A MOVIE. You can actually put pictures of the actual characters there. It's not a LotR game, where using a movie still means you're using Peter Jackson's interpretation of the characters.

The art on both of these games is so bad most of the time that I can't maintain my willing suspension of disbelief. I feel pulled out of the narrative and theme of the game because I look at the cards and think "Have you ever even SEEN a picture of Sigourney Weaver or Bill Paxton?" Or in some cases "Have you ever even SEEN a picture of, like, an anatomically correct human being?"

I hate movie stills in just about everything. Usually I don't like it because the movie version of something is often my least favorite interpretation of a character. But in this case, you can put images of the actual characters on the cards, not an interpretation. Doing otherwise is going to make me like it less.

Anyway, I'm probably the only person that feels this way.

Don't forget to get use out of the other half of the cards by coming golfing with us!


I think of Firefly with this. The game is fine, but the pictures really suck me in. I'd think Alien would be all the better for it. It had to have come up in planning meetings so I wonder if there was another massive charge for using actual photos rather than just likenesses.
item.dc:creator: joestin

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by philmcd

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

Britain supposedly went metric over 40 years ago, but our speeds are still in miles per hour, and personally I still think in feet and inches, pounds and stones, and fahrenheit. I have to mentally convert anything given to me in metric, eg a kilo is a bit over 2 pounds, a litre is 1.76 pints etc. I know 30c is hot, I just can't easily relate it to fahrenheit. 70F is comfortably warm. 80F is hot and 90F is TOO hot. I know where I am with fahrenheit :D
item.dc:creator: philmcd

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by radchad

Related Item: Mage Knight Board Game

Sapper_SB wrote:

Longbombed wrote:

Feel better soon Suzy. 70 is still nice and warm though, but not scorching. Been hitting 2 and 3 here in the evenings. That's like 35*F


Haha!! When I lived in Alaska 70 or 80 was considered warm. Now that I am back in Florida 70 seems cool!

I guess it's all a matter of perspective.


When I was in the states going to school, they kept mentioning that it was 70 or 80 or something. I kept asking myself, "Why can't the States convert to the metric system?"

I still have no idea what the temperature was the entire time I was down there.
item.dc:creator: radchad

fortheloveofdice wrote:

I'm starting to realise how important it is to get a few plays in of a game in close proximity to get the rules down and fully experience what the game has to offer. There are still so many games I want to try (even some I own) but I find it more rewarding to get to know one better before moving on.

That's one of the reasons I don't have many low ratings for games (although I'm not terrible for that). If I really don't have fun I don't want to play it again, but then I feel I haven't given it enough of a chance to judge it.

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by ad79

Related Item: Thunder Alley: Expansion Tracks

Logus Vile wrote:

ad79 wrote:

gentle wrote:

Do you use any special solo variant or are you just playing a few teams yourself?

no special rules, just play each team as best I can. Works for me.


I played it two handed my first game to learn the rules and I had a blast. In fact, I ordered the shapeway plastic cars right away.

I want to run a whole championship with a bunch of teams but I have to admit that I don't usually play multiplayer games solo. So what are your thoughts on "favouritism"? For example, maybe I get attached to the red team and "want" them to win and later on yellow becomes my favourite. Or do you pick a team as "your team" and everyone else is out to get you?

I'm not sure how to approach the game for a solo championship...


You can either just play it as best you can, and maybe you have a favourite team along the way. As long as you don't play the other teams with a "no hurting my favourite team" attitude you should be ok. Allowing longer thoughtprocess for your favourite team is no problem, I think.

Or you can decide before the race how each tema will behave
Red-improve position as often as possible
Green- Stay in the draftline saving solocards for a final push.
Black- cooperative with other teams in hope to gain benefit
Purple- Disrupt for other teams as often as possible as long as it doesn't hurt htemselves more

That kind a thing is possible.

If I do soloseasons for both this and Formula D, I usually root for the underdogs after a few races.
item.dc:creator: ad79

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by gentle

Related Item: Secrets of the Lost Tomb

My game arrived today. Had a look at the minis. Yes, they aren't perfect, with repeated use I can see some of them breaking off at the base. The base is a bit warped with some of them, but they stand upright alright, so I'm not too bothered. But they are cheap, yes.
Though I acutally thought the details on the miniatures were pretty good and with every mini striking a different pose and having a different weapon I can tell them apart a lot easier than the Gears of War minis :)
But to be honest, I actually prefer the standees. They shouldn't have gone for minis in the first place, would've reduced the cost and wouldn't have taken so long.
item.dc:creator: gentle

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by pusherman42

Related Item: Legendary Encounters: A Predator Deck Building Game

Welcome!

I'm completely in the minority on this one, but I would have preferred movie still for both this and Aliens.

The reason is that the source material IS A MOVIE. You can actually put pictures of the actual characters there. It's not a LotR game, where using a movie still means you're using Peter Jackson's interpretation of the characters.

The art on both of these games is so bad most of the time that I can't maintain my willing suspension of disbelief. I feel pulled out of the narrative and theme of the game because I look at the cards and think "Have you ever even SEEN a picture of Sigourney Weaver or Bill Paxton?" Or in some cases "Have you ever even SEEN a picture of, like, an anatomically correct human being?"

I hate movie stills in just about everything. Usually I don't like it because the movie version of something is often my least favorite interpretation of a character. But in this case, you can put images of the actual characters on the cards, not an interpretation. Doing otherwise is going to make me like it less.

Anyway, I'm probably the only person that feels this way.

Don't forget to get use out of the other half of the cards by coming golfing with us!
item.dc:creator: pusherman42

item.title: New comment on Item for Geeklist "Solitaire Games on Your Table - September 2015"
item.description:
by mo7189

Related Item: Rallyman

If I'm being honest with myself, I don't know that I'd still own this if it weren't for the ongoing monthly challenges.

I think the game is really fun. The base game is good. And the expansion is great. It gives me the impression that it would be really great to play with a couple of buddies at the table.

As a solo gamer, you can run any course as a single driver (not very interesting) or as a play all sides four-car race (pretty fun; I've done this a couple times).

But my enjoyment comes from the monthly challenges. Just as with many of the other challenges around these parts, you are playing alone but against the rest of the group. Having other (and generally better, in my case) drivers to compare my times to, banter with, and learn from (I'm still trying to figure that part out) is what makes owning the game more than worthwhile for me.

I've got 40+ plays so far, 15 of which include the Dirt expansion, so I feel I've gotten more than my money's worth from the game.

Pros:
Easy to learn and play.
Tons of variety in track layouts (difficulty and length).
Fun, push your luck style of play.
With Dirt, much more strategy than what appears on the surface.
Component quality is very good.

Cons:
Not as interesting (IMO) without competition from other players (either in person or via PBF).
I really think you need to invest in both the base game and expansion to get the full experience.

Not sure if any of that helps or hurts, but feel free to ask me any questions.

Mo

Oh! An BTW, huge thanks to Shaun for running the challenges every month. The guy's a diamond!!!
item.dc:creator: mo7189
